text:
In J.R.R. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings series, power plays a pivotal and multifaceted role that permeates every aspect of the narrative. The struggles for dominion over Middle-earth serve as a backdrop to explore the nature of power, its corrupting influence, and its effects on individuals and societies.

The primary catalyst driving the plot is the struggle against the dark lord Sauron's quest for absolute power. His singular desire for domination exemplifies the perils of unchecked authority, isomorphic with the warnings sounded by Thomas Hobbes' Leviathan. Sauron's reign represents the zenith of oppressive tyranny, and his perpetual quest for power illuminates the devastating consequences of desiring it above all else.

On the other hand, Gandalf serves as an embodiment of responsible stewardship,3, wielding remarkable sway yet employing it to maintain harmony rather than exploit or subjugate others. Gandalf's exercise of authority offers a counterpoint to Sauron's maniacal thirst, his selflessness proving moral character crucial for responsible governance.

Tolkien also explores the corrosive effects power can have on those seeking it. Gollum, Smagol and Bilbo's experiences highlight how obsessive fixation can consume one's very essence, on this tragic trajectory leading toward darkness and perdition.
